title-group.article-title: Effect of gamma irradiation on some properties of reclaimed rubber/nitrile–butadiene rubber blend and its swelling in motor and brake oils

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Polymer Chemistry, National Center for Radiation Research and Technology, Nasr City, Cairo, Egypt
2Department of Chemistry, Beni Suef University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Medhat M Hassan, Department of Polymer Chemistry, National Center for Radiation Research and Technology, 3 Ahmad El Zomor Street, Nasr City, Cairo 11311, Egypt Email: medhat_smh@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Reclaimed rubber powder (RRP) was treated by the addition of glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) to impart desired properties suitable for oil resistance applications. The produced GMA-RRP was mixed with nitrile–butadiene rubber (NBR) in various compositions. The blends were irradiated with gamma radiation doses of 50–250 kGy. The compounding of the blend factors has been elaborated using Fourier transform infra-red spectroscopy and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Different properties of the synthesized unirradiated and irradiated blends such as tensile strength, elongation at break, hardness, swelling behavior in motor and brake oils and thermal stability were investigated with respect to the RRP content. Results show that the tensile strength, hardness and swelling resistance increase with increasing NBR content in the blend. It has been shown that the tensile strength increased with dose. Similarly, hardness values, reported for the same composition, apparently increased with dose within the range of 50–250 kGy. The residual mass percentage of blends obviously increased upon the incorporation of incremental RRP. The swelling percentage steadily decreases with increasing radiation dose due to the radiation-induced cross-linking.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Acrylonitrile–butadiene rubber (NBR) seals are commercially available for more than 50 years. NBR is known for of its low cost, excellent resistance to oil, fuels and grease, low gas permeability and easy processability. 1 NBR converts itself into the cross-linking type rubber when exposed to high-energy radiation. It is well known that the exposure of cross-linking type polymers to radiation improves the stability and mechanical properties. However, high radiation doses are required to achieve the desired cross-link density. Nevertheless at higher levels of radiation dose, the mechanical properties are adversely affected due to the degradation induced by radiation. 2,3 Its use in automotive applications is interesting but the aging resistance is limited because of the unsaturated backbone of the butadiene. 4 The chemical structure of NBR is shown below

The ever-increasing volume of polymer waste is a severe problem deserving serious attention. Of this polymer waste, only 8–12% comprise plastic, while the rest comprises elastomer. 5 The difficulty in recycling the waste tires is that the scraped tire is a cross-linked polymer that is hard to melt and process. 6 Different types of physical reclaiming processes reported so far are mechanical, thermomechanical, microwave and ultrasound methods. 7 Reclaimed rubber, prepared from scrap rubber, has been used as a substitute for virgin rubber in many rubber compounds. 8 Thus, while this opens up a route for utilizing scrap rubber, it makes the products cheaper. Whole tire reclaimed, a popular form of reclaimed rubber prepared from used and scrap tires, is inherently nonpolar and has been used to prepare blends with nonpolar rubber such as natural rubber (NR), 8 –10 styrene–butadiene rubber (SBR) 11 and butadiene rubber (BR) 12 and also polar rubber such as NBR 13 –15 as well as thermoplastics. 16,17

The effect of ionizing irradiation on polymer blends based on waste rubber (WR)/NR was investigated. 18 Some investigations examined the incorporation of ground rubber powder (GRP) and devulcanized rubber waste as filler and a part of rubber in virgin NR. 19 The GRP and the devulcanized rubber that were generated from passenger car and small truck tires, showed useful mechanical properties in the new rubber compounds, while the compounds that contained devulcanized rubber showed better mechanical properties than those with GRP. 20 Studies were made on using GTR fraction to produce thermoplastic elastomers composed of PE, fresh rubber and GTR with and without dynamic curing. 21

The aim of the present work is to study the effect of gamma (γ) irradiation on the mechanical, thermal and swelling behavior in motor and brake oils. The elucidation of compounding the blend factors has been performed using Fourier transform infra-red spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The investigated properties of the blends were studied before and after irradiation. The developed product is entitled for automotive industries and seal applications.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Reclaimed rubber powder (RRP) of particle size 80 mesh (150 mm) of unclassified ground rubber from the tread and sidewalls of passenger and truck tires were kindly provided by Narobine Company, Cairo, Egypt. NBR, under the commercial name of KRYNAC 4050, was supplied by Bayer, Germany, with an average acrylonitrile content of 30 wt%, Mooney viscosity ML1 + 4 (100°C) 50 + 5 and density 0.98 g/cm3. The reactive compatibilizing agent glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) was obtained from Merck, Germany.

sec.title: Sheet preparation
sec.p: The RRP/NBR/GMA blends at different compositions were prepared in a Brabender-like apparatus. After heating the NBR, the RRP was added into the apparatus, mixed for about 10 min in a temperature range of 170–175°C to disperse the RRP uniformly into the NBR. The GMA of 2 wt% was thereafter added into the blend. After mixing, the samples were hot pressed at about 175°C under 10 MPa for 5 min into sheets of suitable thickness and size for analysis.

sec.title: γ irradiation
sec.p: The blends were submitted to γ irradiation (γ cell type 4000 A, India), in air, at room temperature and in ambient humidity. The absorbed doses were 50, 100, 150, 200 and 250 kGy at a radiation dose of ≈5 kGy/h. Irradiation was carried out at the National Center for Radiation Research and Technology, Atomic Energy Authority, Cairo, Egypt.

sec.title: Mechanical testing
sec.p: Tensile properties of the prepared composites were determined using Hounsfield computer-aided testing machine, England. The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 37-1977 (E) and ISO 34-1975 (E) standards were followed in measuring the tensile strength and elongation at break, respectively.

sec.title: Hardness measurements
sec.p: Samples of at least 1mm in thickness with flat surface were cut for hardness test. The measurement was carried out according to American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D 2240 (ASTM, 2000) using model 306L type Adurometer. The unit of hardness is expressed in A Shore.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a Shimadzu TGA-50 system (Kyoto, Japan) and heated at a temperature range of 20–600°C at a rate of 20°C/min under a controlled dry nitrogen flow of 20 ml/min. T 0.25, T 0.5 and T 0.75 are the temperatures in degree centigrade at which 25%, 50%, and 75%, respectively, mass loss occurs.

sec.title: Morphological characterization
sec.p: ISM-5400 scanning electron microscope (JEOL, Japan) was used for the morphological observation of fracture samples in liquid nitrogen coated with gold before testing.

sec.title: Infrared spectroscopic analysis
sec.p: The infrared spectra were performed using FTIR spectrophotometer, Mattson 100 Unicam, England, over the range of 500–4000 cm−1. A dry constant weight from each blend was ground with 3 mg of KBr and then pressed to form transparent disks. The samples for IR analysis were first dried in a vacuum oven at 80°C for 2 h.

sec.title: Swelling tests
sec.p:
Average swelling was measured using the following method. Three pieces of uniform size and weight (≈0.5 g) of each sample were accurately weighed (W) and immersed in 50 ml of solvent at room temperature for 24 h. After that the sample was taken out and placed in between the two pieces of filter paper, which in turn was placed in between the two sheets of glass (each weighted 98.4 g) and left undisturbed for 5 s and transferred to the weighing bottle and reweighed (Wt). The swelling percentage (Q%) was calculated for each piece using the below equation:
Q % =
W t − W
W
× 100
where W and Wt are the mass of the test piece before swelling and after the time (t) of immersion, respectively. The mass of the sample was measured by electronic digital balance with 1 mg accuracy.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The variation in tensile strength (T s) with the feed ratio of RRP to NBR in presence of GMA is shown in Figure 1. The apparent reduction in tensile strength with the addition of RRP is due to the lower molecular weight of the reclaimed rubber. The high shear and temperature during the reclamation process severely breaks down the molecular chains into shorter segments. Incorporation of this low-molecular-weight fraction results in progressive reduction in the tensile strength. The high-energy irradiation of polymers creates free radicals by the scission of the weakest bonds. These new entities react with each other or with the molecular oxygen. 1 The effect of γ irradiation on T s of RRP/NBR/GMA with various compositions at different radiation doses is shown in Figure 1; the T s of the samples increased with the increase in radiation dose. Tensile strength of RRP/NBR/GMA rubber blend was found to increase continuously within the cited dose range of the present study. This is due to the high cross-link density of the blend cured by high irradiation. The high cross-link density of rubber indicates that the formation of more C–C bonds in the network and more energy is dissipated in the stretching process. Also, with the increase in the extent of cross-linking, the molecules are able to keep in phase with the applied sinusoidal stress field 22 in the mixture containing reclaimed rubber.

caption.p: Tensile strength of nitrile–butadiene rubber (NBR) blended with different ratio of reclaimed rubber powder (RRP) using 2% glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) at various doses of gamma radiation.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the variation in elongation percentage at break (E b) with RRP loading. E b decreases systematically with increasing RRP loading at a dose of 50 kGy; there is a gradual reduction from 1225 to 228% with respect to the increase in RRP from 0 to 80% loading. The low molecular weight and the presence of filler in the pristine RRP may inhibit molecular orientations causing the sample to fail at low elongation. Also, this observation is attributed to the presence of cross-linked rubber particles and other ingredients in RRP, which render them unable to stretch upon deformation, hence limit the flow and mobility of the blends particularly at a higher content of RRP. As the radiation dose increases, all blends in E b increased up to 50 kGy and then decreased. This revealed that the cross-linking of these blends occur at around 50 kGy and at low doses the uncross-linked blends act as plasticizer, hence E b increased, whereas the blends showed a decrease in E b with the increase in absorbed dose. This decrease is due to the formation of a cross-linked structure. However, at high cross-link density, the network is so dense that there is little energy dissipation in the matrix and the energy supplied is utilized for breaking the bonds. At high cross-link density, the segments of macromolecules become immobile, the system becomes stiffer and the elasticity decreases. 23,24

caption.p: Elongation at break of nitrile–butadiene rubber (NBR) blended with different ratios of reclaimed rubber powder (RRP) using 2% glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) at various doses of gamma radiation.

sec.p: The variation in hardness of neat NBR and RRP/NBR/GMA at various compositions as a function of radiation dose is illustrated in Figure 3. The data of unirradiated loaded rubber were introduced in the same figure for comparison. It may be observed that the hardness values increased effectively by increasing the degree of RRP loading. Similar behavior has been attained for radiation blends when comparing its hardness values at the same radiation dose. On the other hand, comparatively marked increase has been attained in the hardness value for the same composition on increasing the radiation dose from 50 to 250 kGy. These data clearly indicate that the contribution to hardness values from radiation-induced cross-linking occurring in the totally amorphous rubber matrix of the blend is appreciable.

caption.p: Variation in hardness of nitrile–butadiene rubber (NBR) blended with different ratios of reclaimed rubber powder (RRP) using 2% glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) at various doses of gamma radiation.

sec.title: Thermal stability of neat polymer and blends
sec.p: The degradation temperature of NBR, RRP and RRP/NBR/GMA blends have been analyzed by the thermogravimetric method that is considered one of the widely used techniques to illustrate the thermal stability of polymers over a wide range of temperature. The initial TGA thermograms for unirradiated and irradiated NBR and its blends with RRP are shown in Figures 4 and 5. Also, Table 1 summarizes the temperature at which different mass loss occurs at different composition ratios before and after γ irradiation.

caption.p: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of unirradiated nitrile–butadiene rubber (NBR) blended with different ratios of reclaimed rubber powder (RRP) using 2% glycidyl methacrylate (GMA).
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of NBR/RRP/GMA (50/50/2 wt%) at various doses of gamma radiation. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.
TGA data of unirradiated and irradiated blend of RRP/NBR exposed to 100 and 200 kGy

fn.p: NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder; TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.

sec.p: As can be seen from Figure 4, the onset of degradation T0.25 was at 449°C, whereas T0.5 at 474°C and T0.75 was at 545°C. Hence, the sample RRP/NBR/GMA (0/100/2 wt%) can be considered as thermally stable up to 449°C. Above 449°C, volatilization becomes very rapid and almost complete decomposition occurs. Thus, no appreciable mass loss in the thermogram above this temperature could be detected. The effect of blend ratio on the TGA thermogram of blend is presented in the same figure. Compared to the degradation pattern of the individual component, the degradation behavior of the blend is different (Table 1). As shown in Table 1, degradation temperature decreases gradually by the addition of waste rubber in blend. Table 1 also gives the percentage mass loss in the specimen at three different temperatures, T(0.25), T(0.50) and T(0.75). As the mass percentage of the rubber in the blend increases, a gradual decrease in mass loss can be noticed, indicating an increase in thermal stability. The initial TGA thermogram and the rate of reaction curves for irradiated blends containing RRP/NBR/GMA, 50/50 are shown in Figure 5. As seen in Table 1, the optimal thermal stability was attained for the RRP/NBR/GMA, 40/60/2 blend, whereby the thermal stability increases with increase in radiation dose, as reported for the blend 50/50, this can be accounted for the radiation intermolecular cross-linking. The residual mass percentage of the blends obviously increased upon the incorporation of incremental RRP.

sec.title: FTIR analysis
sec.p: Chemical changes produced by γ irradiation in polymer matrix were studied by means of FTIR spectroscopy. Figure 6 shows FTIR spectral area of 400–4000 cm−1 for the RRP, NBR and their blend in the presence of GMA in comparison with the neat tire rubber. The band at 1092 cm−1 is assigned to carbon black 25 taken as a reference. The spectral analysis of reused tire shows a weak band at 1723 cm−1, which is associated with the thermal oxidation that occurs as a result of the exposure of the surface to oxygen and induces the formation of an oxidation skin that includes carbonyl groups. The strong band at 1587 cm−1 is associated with C=C polyisoprene, the strong band at 2336 cm−1 is referred to C≡N– group, bands at 1412 cm−1 to the scissoring vibrations of =CH2 (on butadiene), the band at 839 cm−1 to the trans-isopropenyl unit [–C(CH3)=CH–] and the band at 479 cm−1 to the bond S–S. 23 The general spectra of NBR are plotted in the same figure, and the saturation of the methyl/methylene stretching vibrations (2800–3000 cm−1) and nitrile vibrations (2240 cm−1) are observed. Several articles indicate that no change was observed in the band reprehensive CN. 26 –28 The small peak at 2183 cm−1, which can be attributed to the conjugated nitrile groups does not change during irradiation.

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of RRP/NBR/GMA at various compositions. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile-butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

sec.p: Figure 7 displays the FTIR spectra of unirradiated RRP and its blends with NBR at different ratios. The hydrocarbon compounds are represented by a strong band of multiple peaks near 2813 cm−1 and in the interval between 1451 and 1334 cm−1. Such bands correspond to different vibrational modes of the –CH2 sequences. 29 The characteristic band corresponding to the vibrational movement of –C–H of the CH3 group, approximately at 1370 cm−1, can also be seen. Additionally, the spectra display many sharp peaks of medium intensity in the 1250–833 cm−1 region. In the given spectra of NBR, the band at 2350 cm−1 is ascribed to alkyl –CN stretching vibrations, whose intensities increase with the NBR content, whereas the band at 960 cm−1 is due to the C–H wagging motion vibration of butadiene. The characteristic absorption bands of polymer blend are: stretching vibration of –C–O at 1672 cm−1, deformation vibration of N–H at 1539 cm−1, stretching vibration of –C–N at 1270 cm−1 and bending vibration of –C–O and –N–H within 580–690 cm−1.

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of RRP/NBR/GMA (50/50/2 wt%) at various doses of gamma irradiation. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

sec.p: Only minor variations are induced by irradiation as shown in Figure 7. It is thought that in NBR, double bonds are rather expected to increase the cross-linking efficiency due to the reaction of macroradicals with these double bonds. 27 The degree of radiation-induced cross-linking can be estimated directly by evaluating the decrease in the IR intensity at about 1655 cm−1 (C=C) and at about 965 cm−1 (transvinylidene C=C) or at 1446 cm−1 (methylene deformation induced by C=O). 30 An overall increase in the absorption between 1660 and 1750 cm−1 is mainly observed and can be attributed to oxidation (C=O, C–O–C…) and conjugation of –C≡N– or –C≡C–. A small peak appearing around 3370 cm−1, especially by the highest doses, may indicate either oxidation or the presence of –C≡N–H bonds. 31

sec.title: Oil resistance of neat polymer and blends
sec.p: The oil resistance of a rubber is one of the key characteristics in the final selection of the rubber to be used, especially in automotive, industries and seal applications. Oil resistance is the reciprocal of the degree of swelling in oil and is governed by the competition between the driving force toward “dissolution of the rubber in the low-molecular-weight oil,” that is swelling, and the elastic force that increases upon oil uptake. 32 Figures 8 and 9 show the effect of partial replacement of NBR with RRP on the swelling behavior of RRP/NBR/GMA blends in ASTM motor oil and brake oil, respectively, for 7 days. The swelling equilibrium has been attained after 6 h. It can be noted that the swelling percentage decreases with increasing RRP content in the blend. This observation is due to the cross-linking of rubber particles and other ingredients in RRP, which could limit the penetration of solvents into the blends particularly at higher content of RRP. 18 It was found that the developed blends in the selected oils basically obey the first-order absorption kinetics, and the value of the swelling kinetic constant K at equilibrium for motor oil is larger than that for brake oil at all implemented feed ratios. This means that the oil-absorption rate of the blend matrices in motor oil is larger than that in brake oil. This is believed to be due to the fact that the viscosity of motor oil is smaller than brake oil, and its molecules can later diffuse into the cross-linked network.

caption.p: Swelling–time relationship of partial replacement of NBR with RRP for NBR/RRP/GMA blends in motor oil. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile-butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.
Swelling–time relationship of partial replacement of NBR with RRP for NBR/RRP/GMA blends in brake oil. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

sec.p: These similar outcomes have been obtained after irradiation. Relative diminishing in the swelling percentage value of the irradiated specimens has been noticed in comparison with the unirradiated respective ones. It is a well-known fact that an increase in the amount of cross-linking causes the formation of a denser network and reduces the chain length between cross-links and thereby diminishes oil absorbency. 18

caption.p: Swelling–time relationship of NBR/RRP/GMA (50/50/2 wt%) blends in motor oil at different doses of gamma radiation. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile-butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

Swelling–time relationship of NBR/RRP/GMA (50/50/2 wt%) blends in brake oil at different doses of gamma radiation. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

sec.title: Scanning Electron Microscopy
sec.p: Figures 12 and 13 show the SEM comparison of tensile fracture surfaces of RRP/NBR/GMA unirradiated and irradiated blends at ×200 magnifications. The micrographs of unirradiated NBR in Figure 12(a) show an irregular domain size and shape of the NBR giving rise to the appearance of a spongy matrix. The effect of partial replacement of NBR with RRP on the morphology of the tensile fracture surface of the blends is shown in Figure 12(c and d). This figure shows almost similar features at the same size and number of the dispersed domain. Figure 12(b) shows a low dispersed domain and pore size. This indicates that during the reclamation process the break down of molecular chains is severe. The micrographs of irradiated RRP/NBR/GMA blends in Figure 13(b and c) exhibit relatively smooth surface, compared with Figure 12(a) which indicates that the cross-linking occurred between the components of RRP as a result of radiation. These micrographs explain the reduction in the tensile strength with increasing RRP loading. According to the micrograph of Figure 13(b) the morphology of the irradiated NBR/RRP (50/50) blend exhibits a relatively smooth surface with many vacuoles and undispersed agglomerates that disappear in the irradiated blends.

caption.p: Scanning electron micrographs of NBR and blended with varying contents of RRP: (a) NBR, (b) RRP/NBR/GMA 40/60, (c) RRP/NBR/GMA 50/50, (d) RRP/NBR/GMA 60/40 and RRP. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

Scanning electron micrographs of RRP/NBR/GMA 50/50/2 wt% blends at different doses of gamma radiation: (a) 0 kGy, (b) 100 kGy and (c) 200 kGy. GMA: glycidyl methacrylate; NBR: nitrile–butadiene rubber; RRP: reclaimed rubber powder.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This work illustrates the effect of γ irradiation on the physicomechanical properties of NBR/waste rubber powder (WRP)/GMA blends. The following conclusions can be drawn from this study:

list-item.p: The tensile strength of unirradiated RRP/NBR/GMA blends shows low values with the addition of RRP. Meanwhile, the T s of the samples increased with the increase in radiation dose.
E b decreases systematically with increasing RRP loading at a dose of 50 kGy. As the radiation dose increases, all blends showed an increase in E b up to 50 kGy and then decreased.

The hardness values have effectively increased by increasing the degree of loading with the RRP; comparatively marked increase has been attained in the value of hardness for the same composition by increasing the radiation dose from 50 to 250 kGy.
Degradation temperature decreases gradually by the addition of waste rubber in RRP/NBR/GMA blend and the residual mass percentage of blends obviously increased upon the addition of incremental RRP.

It can be noted that the swelling percentage in both motor and brake oils decreases with increasing RRP content in the blend. Further, the swelling percentage steadily decreased with increasing radiation dose due to the radiation-induced cross-linking.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors would like to thank the financial support from Academy Of Scientific Research, Cairo, Egypt
